citeinfo.title: Large River Monitoring Forum Biogeographic Analysis Package

descript.abstract: The Large River Monitoring Forum compiled fish assemblage data for five large rivers in the U.S. as a part of a coordinated effort to compare and contract river monitoring efforts in large river systems. Fish community data from five monitoring programs were integrated to create the standardized dataset. The Large River Monitoring Forum Biogeographic Analysis Package was created to calculate biodiversity indices useful in describing ecological communities.
descript.purpose:
These data were created from a database including fish assemblage data for five large rivers in the U.S. The rivers included the Columbia, Colorado, Mississippi, Illinois and the Tallapoosa. For each river fish monitoring data were compiled across time (years) and space (river reach). The database includes the spatial and tabular data for each of the five river systems. A master species file is included in the database which provides a list of all of the species encountered in the data that were compiled with a standard taxonomy and coding system applied. In addition the status of the species as native or non-native in each of the rivers was documented to support the analysis. The data were used to conduct river specific fish community analyses and to investigate the response of the fish assemblages to location and time.
Data from tables in the database were used to calculate biodiversity indices (Margalef, Shannon-Wiener, Simpson's, Hill Numbers, Pielou) for fish assemblages sampled at each stretch of each river in the database. Data were analyzed with the python programming language, utilizing the Math library, the Numpy and Pandas data analysis libraries and plotted using the matplotlib library.

idinfo.useconst: These analyses were created specifically to supplement data related to fish assemblages on portions five large rivers of the Continental US. 16 biodiversity indices were calculated for each stretch of the five major rivers (Colorado, Columbia, Illinois, Mississippi, and Tallapoosa) and indices were graphed against time. The Anaconda/Jupyter Notebook software packages were used to create and share these analyses via GitHub (https://github.com/usgs-bcb/LRMF-Biodiversity-BAP). Python 3.6 was utilized along with the Math, Matplotlib, Numpy and Pandas modules. Application of these analyses to other assemblage data requires input comma separated text files which follow the same formatting as the inputs used for these analyses which is detailed in the README.md at https://github.com/cbelyea/LRMF-Biodiversity-BAP

cntperp.cntorg: USGS Core Science Analytics, Synthesis & Libraries

idinfo.datacred:
The Large River Monitoring Forum includes representatives from the U.S. Geological Survey, Illinois Natural Heritage Survey, Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife and the Pacific Northwest Aquatic Monitoring Partnership. The USGS affiliates represent the Western Fisheries Research Center, Oregon Water Science Center, Upper Midwest Environmental Sciences Center, Grand Canyon Monitoring and Research Center, Alabama Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Center, Missouri Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Center, and the Core Science Analytics, Synthesis & Libraries.
Analyses were performed by Biodiversity and Spatial Information Center at North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC.

attracc.attraccr: Attributes were reviewed for accuracy. Results from biodiveristy indices calculations were checked against results obtained from Primer-e 7 software.

dataqual.complete: The data have been determined to be 100% complete

srcinfo.srccontr: Source information used in support of the development of the data set.

procstep.procdesc: The data were brought together from five river monitoring programs. For each river the raw data were provided as the number of each fish species captured in each river segment and year. Prior to compiling the database, the principal investigator for each river system worked with the GIS analyst to identify the full extent of the river system that was sampled and how sampling locations on the river should be grouped to create the river segments used in the analysis.
Raw data files from each of the five large river systems were brought into single excel file (one worksheet/river system).

A master species list was compiled for all five of the large river systems. The Master Species list standardized the taxonomy (genus and species) and provided the four digit code for each of the species in the list that was used in the database tables. In addition the native status of each species for each of the five rivers was documented.

Given the diversity of monitoring projects being brought together it was important to provide some standardization. The data from the Upper Mississippi River Restoration Program represented the longest running and most standardized dataset and was used as a guideline for getting the remaining datasets into a common framework.

For rivers using a different coding system for their species, modified the species data tables to incorporate the codes from the master species list, and brought in the scientific and common names for each species.
Used pivot tables to transform each of the species data table so that the species records would represent rows, and the columns would represent the sampling events (reach/year).
Converted the total number of individuals by species/sample/reach/year.

Tables from the geodatabase were added to a dataframe in the Environmental Systems Research Institute (ESRI) software ArcMap. From there, the tables were opened and exported from ESRI proprietary format to comma separated value text files.
A Jupyter Notebook was set up with Python 3.6, Numpy, Pandas and Matplotlib.
The comma separated text files were then read into Pandas dataframes and the speices information contained within were then used to calculate the biodiversity indices of interest.
Each river reach was iterated over for each index, plotting the index for all stretches against time (years).
Once the index data were plotted, the plot was exported locally to .png format.

overview.eaover: The entity and attribute information provided here describe diversity index calculations derived from a geodatabase containing 5 vector digital data (polyline) for large rivers and 6 tabular datasets (5 rivers and 1 species list). Please review the detailed descriptions that are provided (the individual attribute descriptions) for information on the values that appear as fields/table entries of the data set.
overview.eadetcit: The entity and attribute information was generated by the individual and/or agency identified as the originator of the data set. Please review the rest of the metadata record for additional details and information.

distinfo.distliab: Distributor assumes no liability for misuse of data.

stdorder.fees: None. No fees are applicable for obtaining the data set.

cntperp.cntorg: USGS Core Science Analytics, Synthesis & Libraries

metainfo.metstdn: Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata
metainfo.metuc: These data represent a highly derived dataset from each of the five river system and therefore are appropriate to specific research questions. The spatial aggregation of sampling sites into river segments are based on the scientific expertise represented by the Large River Monitoring Forum members. Re-analysis of the data needs to be consistent with the spatial and temporal framework incorporated here. Only data specific to two types of sampling were included in the dataset, electrofishing (Colorado, Tallapoosa, Illinois & Upper Mississippi) and gillnetting (Columbia) therefore the full fish assemblage of a river system may not be represented in the data compiled for this study.
